title: MaxUnpool2d breaks for certain shaped inputs
body_html:
The given code:

import torch
from torch import nn
from torch.autograd import Variable

data = Variable(torch.rand(1, 3, 540, 960))

pool = nn.MaxPool2d(2, 2, return_indices=True)
unpool = nn.MaxUnpool2d(2, 2)

out, indices1 = pool(data)
out, indices2 = pool(out)
out, indices3 = pool(out)

out = unpool(out, indices3)
out = unpool(out, indices2) 
out = unpool(out, indices1)

produces the error:

RuntimeError: input and indices shapes do not match: input [1 x 3 x 134 x 240], indices [1 x 3 x 135 x 240] at /.../pytorch/torch/lib/THNN/generic/SpatialMaxUnpooling.c:66

But if I use a differently sized data (e.g. (1, 3, 480, 480)) it does not.

edit: Forgot to add, this is for the CPU. I haven't had a chance to test CUDA yet.
body_text:
The given code:

from torch import nn
from torch.autograd import Variable

data = Variable(torch.rand(1, 3, 540, 960))

out, indices2 = pool(out)
out, indices3 = pool(out)

out = unpool(out, indices3)
out = unpool(out, indices2) 
out = unpool(out, indices1)
produces the error:

RuntimeError: input and indices shapes do not match: input [1 x 3 x 134 x 240], indices [1 x 3 x 135 x 240] at /.../pytorch/torch/lib/THNN/generic/SpatialMaxUnpooling.c:66

But if I use a differently sized data (e.g. (1, 3, 480, 480)) it does not.
edit: Forgot to add, this is for the CPU. I haven't had a chance to test CUDA yet.
body:
The given code:

```Python
import torch
from torch import nn
from torch.autograd import Variable

data = Variable(torch.rand(1, 3, 540, 960))

pool = nn.MaxPool2d(2, 2, return_indices=True)
unpool = nn.MaxUnpool2d(2, 2)

out, indices1 = pool(data)
out, indices2 = pool(out)
out, indices3 = pool(out)

out = unpool(out, indices3)
out = unpool(out, indices2) 
out = unpool(out, indices1)
```

produces the error: 
> RuntimeError: input and indices shapes do not match: input [1 x 3 x 134 x 240], indices [1 x 3 x 135 x 240] at /.../pytorch/torch/lib/THNN/generic/SpatialMaxUnpooling.c:66

But if I use a differently sized data (e.g. (1, 3, 480, 480)) it does not.

**edit**: Forgot to add, this is for the CPU. I haven't had a chance to test CUDA yet.
